clinical_study.brief_title: A Factorial Approach to Improve Treatment Adherence
clinical_study.official_title: Efficacy of a mHealth Intervention for Treatment Adherence in Adult Hypertensive Patients: a Randomized Controlled Trial With Factorial Design

brief_summary.textblock: Poor medication adherence is a crucial operational factor for uncontrolled hypertension prevalence in Pakistan. Technology-based mobile phone interventions are available at the forefront and a relatively cheap tool to combat the recent health challenges related to poor adherence. This study will assess the impact of mobile health-based multimodal approach intervention to enhance medication adherence in patients with hypertension.

detailed_description.textblock:
Hypertension is indeed a significant public health concern in Pakistan. Hypertension drastically affects 18.9% of adolescents of age greater than 15 and 33% of adults above 45; less than 3% of hypertensive patients, however, have their blood pressure controlled to 140/90 mm Hg or below. The results of the meta-analysis showed optimal adherence can result in poor outcomes by 26%. Poor medication adherence is the cause of poor control of blood pressure in Pakistan. The majority of patients on hypertensive medication are found to have uncontrolled blood pressure. A majority of the population on treatment were found to be non-adherent. The adherence to cardiac medicines was reported as ranging from 27-77% and about 68% to stroke medicines. In a recent study, 37.7% of patients were non-adherent to the prescribed antihypertensive therapy.
This study will seek mobile health interventions' effectiveness by using our different modules in improving patients' treatment adherence and alleviating blood pressure in hypertensive patients. If this study finds significant results it can help develop educational guidelines for patients to improve their medication adherence and reduce related complications at the same time. We will give a new line of research for coming researchers eventually.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: It is a factorial design, intention-to-treat, four-arm, single-blinded randomized controlled trial, six months of duration with an intervention pre-test and post-test evaluation to analyze the efficacy of mobile health using four different educational and reminder modules interventions to improve treatment adherence on clinical grounds in hypertensive patients in a tertiary care hospital of Lahore, Pakistan.

primary_outcome.description: The primary outcome is a change in systolic blood pressure (SBP) of participants at 0, 3, and 6 months. The blood pressure will be recorded by sphygmomanometer used was calibrated upper-arm electronic sphygmomanometer (OMRON HEM-7200, OMRON Corporation, Dalian). Two separate readings will be taken within 5 min, and the average measurement will be the final. If the difference between the two measurements will be more than 5mmHg, then a third recording will be done and the average is considered.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in medication adherence to antihypertensive treatment
secondary_outcome.description: The secondary outcome is the change in medication adherence to antihypertensive treatment. Using the SEAMS questionnaire and "pills taken over a certain period, divided by pills prescribed for that specific period", the primary outcome will be measured. Both of the above-mentioned information will be self-reporting. The SEAMS is a 13-item questionnaire that has three-point responses. The score for the 13-item scale ranges from 13 to 39. Higher scores show better levels of self-efficacy for medication adherence and vice versa. A cut-off value of 80% has been established from previous literature. Non-adherents will make up less than 80% of the population, while adherents will make up more than 80%.

arm_group.description: The first group will be on standard care as usually being practiced in hospitals.
The second group will receive daily written notes and voice messages in addition to standard care.
The third group will receive daily Graphic based reminders and once weekly an animated video along with standard care.
The fourth group along with standard care will receive written notes, voice messages, Graphic based reminders on daily basis, and once the weekly animated video in addition to standard care.

intervention.description: Group B will receive daily written notes and voice messages (For example, "Good Morning, "It's your medicine time." "Good Morning, "This is to remind you of your medication" in Urdu and English languages), in addition to standard care through WhatsApp as a reminder for medication

intervention.intervention_name: Graphic based reminders and once weekly an animated video
intervention.description: Group C will receive daily Graphic based reminders and once weekly an animated video regarding educational support and the outcome of disease, The video has three parts 1) knowledge about hypertension 2) complications of uncontrolled hypertension 3) medical and lifestyle adaptation for good health which resultantly improves adherence. along with standard care.

intervention.intervention_name: written notes, voice messages, Graphic based reminders , and animated video
intervention.description: Group D will receive written notes, voice messages (For example, "Good Morning, "It's your medicine time." "Good Morning, "This is to remind you of your medication" in Urdu and English languages), Graphic based reminders daily, and once weekly an animated video regarding educational support and the outcome of disease, The video has three parts 1) knowledge about hypertension 2) complications of uncontrolled hypertension 3) medical and lifestyle adaptation for good health which resultantly improves adherence. along with standard care.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients with age more than 18 years
- Patients diagnosed with hypertension and registered in the OPDs of Cardiology and Medicine department in Shaikh Zayed Hospital, Lahore, for at least last one month
- Patients on antihypertensive drugs
- Patients with poor medication adherence ( Less than 80% measured by SEAMS and pill counting information)
- Single-member from one family
- Patients with smartphones and using "WhatsApp" application
Exclusion Criteria:
- Participants who sufferers with the planned journey within two months without internet signals area Participants who suffer from some type of malignancy and require adjustment of drugs
- Participants who sufferers with any planned procedure like CABG, PCI, or CEA (Carotid Endarterectomy), as need immediate changes in their medication
- Participants in hypertensive emergency blood pressure >220/120 mmHg
- Participants with pregnancy(self-reporting)
- Participants in their period of lactation
